Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Energy-Shared Computing in Sustainable Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: With increasing network connectivity available, data generated by embedded sensor devices have been effectively shared in many collaborative applications, such as sensor data collection, environmental monitoring, and wearable computing. Data sharing has been a research topic for many years, with hundreds of related projects. In contrast, the concept of energy sharing among multiple embedded sensor devices has captured very little attention. Until now, energy has been predominately harvested and consumed locally in a single embedded sensor device. In this project, we attempt to lay a foundation for energy sharing among sustainable sensor devices. The outcome of this research will constitute a significant advance in the development of theoretical foundations and practical algorithms for designing and improving energy efficiency of sustainable sensor networks. The broader impact of this work shall be amplified by (i) improving course development and student training; (ii) increasing research participation of minorities, women, and Native Americans; (iii) facilitating international dissemination of research findings; (iv) raising interest in technology among K-12 students and other under-represented minority groups; and (v) fostering interdisciplinary collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI’s group has built a novel energy-shared hardware platform and an energy-shared network architecture for sustainable sensor networks. The PI’s group has also applied the design principles and general guidelines of the energy-sharing concept in robotic sensor networks, smart-grids, and electrical vehicles in smart cities. The PI’s group has successfully i) established international collaborations (e.g., with Dr. Ping Yi at Shanghai Jiaotong University, China and Dr. Daniel Menasche at Federal University of Rio de Janerio in Brazil), and ii) published more than 20 papers at premier conferences and in journals including SenSys, ICNP, INFOCOM, ICDE, ICCPS, BuildSys, BigData, SmartGridComm, e-Energy, TOSN, TMC, TECS, and TON. Two papers were nominated for the Best Paper Award in the 4th ACM International Conference on Future Energy Systems (e-Energy 2013) and the 1st ACM International Conference on Embedded Systems for Energy-Efficient Buildings (BuildSys 2014), respectively.

Besides the research accomplishment, the PI has i) developed two new graduate-level courses Cyber-Physical Systems and Sensing and Control for Smart Energy. The developed course materials have been shared within UMBC, and among other universities (including Binghamton University, University of Colorado, Northeast University, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Jilin University, and Singapore University of Technology and Design). The PI has also supervised multiple projects that contain 4 graduate (including one Ph.D. dissertation) and 5 undergraduate students. Under the PI’s guidance, one of his female undergraduate students has been nominated for the prestigious Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship. Supported by the Research Experience for Undergraduates Supplements, one of the undergraduate students (David Skoda) has coauthored a top conference paper (i.e., IEEE International Conference on Big Data).

The PI has also organized two special issues to disseminate the results to communities of interest and facilitate the discussion of latest technologies in the specific communities. These two special issues are “Special Issue on Big Data in Future Sensing” and “Recent Advances in Internet of Things (IoT): Protocols, Algorithms, and Applications”.
